snippet.title: Industry association partners with non-bank lender
snippet.content: The Mortgage & Finance Association of Australia () has teamed up with non-bank lender to deliver a series of workshops to new-to-industry brokers. These sessions will be free for member brokers and will provide realistic insights, planning tools, and profit & loss skills so participants can create an action plan for their individual business success. The program has been running for 12 months prior to the newly announced partnership and is being delivered in the five major capital cities. "The workshops offer real value for brokers who need practical advice on business growth and performance measurement. Many of the participants are enthusiastic but these sessions also give brokers a realistic set of expectations which can often help them to establish the difference between a long-term business or failure," said CEO . "Additionally, the sessions develop a peer network that can offer support, along with feedback from the BDM on connections that can help deliver positive consumer outcomes." Pepper has stepped forward to support new-to-industry brokers as a way to create a more sustainable future in the broker channel. Through its support, the lender will also provide brokers with a better suite of solutions for clients. "The truth is, every customer that comes through the door has a different set of circumstances - and right now, 40% of them are under serviced. It's important for new brokers to know all the available options so that they can be a point of difference in the industry," said 's director of sales and distribution, Aaron Milburn. "A lot of these non-conforming deals seem difficult, but with the right tools and support, brokers can achieve a successful business. We hope that we can provide that support together with the ." Those attending these sessions will be provided with comprehensive workbooks - reference materials which will guide them through the business management process. "Seventy-two per cent of brokers who are new to the industry are still in the industry a year later, and this workshop program has certainly contributed to that success rate. The longevity of the broker channel relies on educated, savvy brokers joining and staying in the industry, and we are excited to partner with in making that happen," Felton said. Related stories:
